questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty with a syncopal attack. His ECG was as shown below. The drug of choice for the following condition is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adenosine In the above given ECG- The R-R interval is shortened and there is tachycardia Narrow QRS complex ST segment depression hidden P waves These changes are seen in the case of AVNRT/PSVT The drug of choice for AVNRT/PSVT is Adenosine

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Procainamide is the Drug of choice in WPW syndrome. Intravenous procainamide is also used in very irregular wide-complex tachycardia which is most likely pre excited AF or flutter Option C- Ibutilide is used in Atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter Option D - Verapamil is used in a case of Multifocal atrial tachycardia. Verapamil is also used in cases of Atrial Fibrillation for rate control.

questions.text: Match the following ECG with the condition causing it- Atrial Flutter Atrial fibrillation AVNRT Multifocal atrial tachycardia Select the correct answer from given below code:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-(iv), 2-(i), 3-(ii), 4-(iii) All the ECGs given above show Tachycardia (decreased RR interval) ECG 1. There is an Irregular RR interval with varying P wave morphology (>3). These changes are seen in Multifocal atrial tachycardia ECG 2 . The sawtooth pattern of the P wave is seen in the ECG, suggestive of Atrial flutter ECG 3 . There is an Irregular RR interval with an absent P wave, Suggestive of atrial fibrillation ECG 4. There is a Narrow QRS complex, ST segment depression and hidden P waves. These changes are seen in the case of AVNRT/PSVT

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic suddenly develops palpitation after an alcohol binge. Which of the following arrhythmia is most commonly seen in this patient following the alcohol binge-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

D Binge drinking (consuming large amounts of alcohol in a short time period) can trigger a bout of atrial fibrillation . ECG 4 – is of Atrial fibrillation. There is an Irregular RR interval with an absent P wave

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - ECG 1- is of Monomorphic VT. It shows the Wide QRS complex. Monomorphic VT has the same QRS complex from beat to beat, indicating that the activation sequence is the same from beat to beat and that each beat likely originates from the same source. Option B - ECG 2- is of polymorphic VT. polymorphic VT has a continually changing QRS morphology indicating a changing ventricular activation sequence. Polymorphic VT that occurs in the context of congenital or acquired prolongation of the QT interval often has a waxing and waning QRS amplitude creating a “twisting about the points” appearance referred to as Torsade de Pointes Option C- ECG 3- is of atrial flutter. Saw tooth pattern of the P wave is seen in the ECG

questions.text: The below ECG was recorded in a 45 year old obese patient. She is a K/c/o Hypertension . Choose the correct answer for the ECG given-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atrial fibrillation Risk factors for developing AF in addition to age and underlying cardiac disease include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, cardiac disease, obesity, and sleep apnea. AF is associated with a 1.5- to 1.9-fold increased risk of mortality after controlling for underlying heart disease. The ECG shows an Irregular RR interval with an absent P wave thus the condition is Atrial fibrillation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - In LVH S V1 + R V5 >35 mm Also in LVH R wave>11mm in lead aVL not seen in this ECG Option C - The ECG above does not show Extreme axis deviation Option D - In aortic dissection ECG findings of MI are seen

questions.text: Focal atrial tachycardia is an arrhythmia with electrical impulses originating and confined within the atria. Focal tachycardia typically occurs in the setting of increased metabolic demand and stress, like infection, hypoxia, etc. ECG of a patient suffering from Focal Atrial Tachycardia may show all of the following except-

options.label: A
options.text: P wave morphology depends on the location of the focus

options.label: C
options.text: P-R interval shorter than the R-P interval

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Absent P wave The absent P wave is usually seen in Atrial fibrillation Focal Atrial tachycardia typically presents with 1:1 AV conduction or with AV block that can be Wenckebach-type conduction or fixed (e.g., 2:1 or 3:1).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A & C - When 1:1 conduction to the ventricles is present- the arrhythmia can resemble sinus tachycardia typically with a P-R interval shorter than the R-P interval, particularly when sympathetic tone produces rapid AV nodal conduction. It can be distinguished from sinus tachycardia by the P-wave morphology, which usually differs from sinus p waves depending on the location of the focus. Focal AT tends to originate in areas of complex atrial anatomy, such as the crista terminalis, valve annuli, atrial septum, and atrial muscle extending along cardiac thoracic veins (superior vena cava, coronary sinus, and pulmonary veins), and the location can often be estimated by the P-wave morphology. AT from the atrial septum will frequently have a narrower P-wave duration than sinus rhythm. AT from the left atrium will usually have a monophasic, positive P wave in lead V1 and negative P waves in I and aVL Option D - During 2:1 conduction- depending on the atrial rate, the P wave may fall on top of the T wave or, the P wave may fall coincident with the QRS.

questions.text: Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) are extra heartbeats that begin in one of the heart's two lower pumping chambers. These extra beats disrupt the regular heart rhythm, sometimes causing a sensation of a fluttering or a skipped beat in the chest. All of the following may be seen in ventricular premature beats except-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Narrow QRS complex Narrow QRS complex is not seen in ventricular premature beats, instead a Wide QRS complex is seen.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- O ption B- Wide QRS complex is seen. Option C- Fusion beat seen in ventricular premature beats. Option D- capture beats seen in ventricular premature beats.

questions.text: All of the following can help differentiate ventricular tachycardia and supraventricular tachycardia except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ventricular rate >180/minute A ventricular rate > 100/min is seen in both ventricular tachycardia and supraventricular tachycardia, thus a Ventricular rate >180/minute cannot be used to differentiate the two.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B -Ventricular tachycardia is a wide complex tachycardia with QRS duration >0.12second and supraventricular tachycardia is a narrow complex tachycardia with QRS duration <0.12second Option C- Supraventricular tachycardia can be relieved by carotid sinus massage while ventricular tachycardia cannot be relieved by carotid sinus massage Option D- Variable first heart sound is a feature of Ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old unconscious male with acute alcohol intoxication was brought to the emergency department. His relative informed that the patient had complained of chest pain and breathlessness. On examination- Pulse- 160/min, BP- 70/40mmHg. ECG showed absent P waves with irregularly irregular RR interval. TTE showed clots in the left atrium. Which of the following is not done-

options.label: B
options.text: Verapamil is given to reduce the heart rate

options.label: D
options.text: Open mitral commissurotomy and removal of the clot

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardioversion with balloon valvotomy The above condition is atrial fibrillation Cardioversion is not done in this patient as when the normal sinus rhythm starts and when proper atrial contraction occurs, it can cause dislodgement of the clot from the atria.

Highyeild:

CHADVAS Score: -For anticoagulation CCF:-1 Stroke/TIA: 2 HTN:-1 Vascular Pathology:-1 Age 75:-2 Age 65-75:- 1 DM:-1 Sex:- Female:-1 .>2 for male } Anticoagulants >3 for females

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - Verapamil/ diltiazem is given to reduce the heart rate in this patient. Option- C - Anticoagulant therapy Option -D- Open mitral commissurotomy and removal of the clot are also to be done in this patient.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding treatment of this condition except-

options.label: D
options.text: Diltiazem is used for rate control

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Electrical cardioversion is effective The ECG given shows- Irregular RR interval varying P wave morphology (>3) Tachycardia (shortened R-R interval) These changes are seen in Multifocal atrial tachycardia. Therefore, other options are incorrect.

Highyeild:

Therapy for MAT- It is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities. Electrical cardioversion is ineffective. Thus option (a) is false The calcium channel blockers verapamil or diltiazem may slow the atrial and ventricular rate - Option D. MAT may respond to amiodarone, but long-term therapy with this agent is usually avoided due to its toxicities, particularly pulmonary fibrosis- Option C Patients with severe pulmonary disease often do not tolerate beta-blocker therapy.

questions.text: An ECG of the patient shows wide QRS complex tachycardia. All of the following in the ECG indicates ventricular tachycardia except-
questions.correct_answer: D. Typical Right bundle branch block
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Typical Right bundle branch block Wide complex tachycardia due to ventricular tachycardia shows a QRS complex of duration>0.14 seconds, which does not mimic typical RBBB or LBBB QRS complexes It is in supraventricular tachycardia where there is the presence of wide QRS complex tachycardia with typical RBBB or LBBB

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A - Left axis deviation, is a feature of ventricular tachycardia Option B- Fusion beats are a feature of ventricular tachycardia Option C - Atrioventricular dissociation is a feature of ventricular tachycardia.
